We have been using Junit purely at the API level for over a year and this h=
as led to a much more stable product base.  Beginning with 0 Junit tests in=
 place, we had the choice of writing pure unit tests or approaching it at a=
 higher level.  In the interest of time, we chose to write at the same leve=
l that internal consumers and external customers would be doing, beginning =
with the APIs projected as being the 'most used'.  In a perfect world, we w=
ould "do it all" but given time and resource constraints we went for the mo=
st 'bang for the buck' in this product cycle.  While this wasn't intended t=
o be a total replacement for pure unit tests, in theory if you cover all th=
e exposed API's and their permutations of arguments, you are testing everyt=
hing that can be reached by external means (we're not there yet, nor close =
:).  Coupling this strategy with Continuous Integration using Cruise Contro=
l where the tests are run upon every code/testware push to cvs has greatly =
improved
confidence in product stability, not to mention that it has caught=
 numerous bugs the moment they were introduced.

So, I see your strategy as=
 very pragmatic but would also encourage in a secondary thread the developm=
ent of pure unit tests, possibly beginning with new classes as they are cre=
ated.
